params.question: You have a scatterplot of two variables, x and y, and you want to add a straight line that represents the linear regression fit to to the data. Which R function can you use to accomplish this?

answers.text:
plot(x, y, col = "blue", main = "Scatterplot of X vs. Y", xlab = "X", ylab = "Y")
abline(lm(y ~ x), col = "red")

plot(x, y, col = "red", main = "Scatterplot of X vs. Y", xlab = "X", ylab = "Y")
abline(lm(y ~ x), col = "blue")

plot(x ~ y, col = "blue", main = "Scatterplot of Y vs. X", xlab = "X", ylab = "Y")
abline(lm(x~ y), col = "red")

params.question: You want to create a scatterplot to visualize the relationship between two variables, x and y. The scatterplot should have a fitting title, a blue color for the data points, and a regression line overlaid in red. Which code chunk correctly generates this scatterplot?

answers.text:
data <- data[order(data$temp),]
plot(data$days, data$temp, type = "l", xlab = "Day of Month", ylab = "Temperature (°C)")

plot(data$days, data$temp, type = "p", xlab = "Day of Month", ylab = "Temperature (°C)")
abline(data$temp~data$days)

data <- data[order(data$days),]
plot(data$days, data$temp, type = "p", xlab = "Day of Month", ylab = "Temperature (°C)")
abline(data$temp, data$days)

data <- data[order(data$days),]
plot(data$days, data$temp, type = "l", xlab = "Day of Month", ylab = "Temperature (°C)")

params.question:
You have a dataset that represents the daily temperature readings over a month. 

The data looks like this (first 4 rows):

Day | Temp

   1  |  25

   3  |  27

  10 |  31

   2  |   26

You want to create a line plot to visualize the temperature trends. Which code snippet correctly generates a line plot with the x-axis representing the day of the month and the y-axis representing the temperature readings?
